name: xylophone
definition: A percussion instrument consisting of a mounted row of wooden bars that are graduated in length to sound a chromatic scale, played with two small mallets.
description:
The xylophone is a percussion musical instrument that consists of wooden bars struck by mallets. Each bar is tuned to a pitch of a musical scale.

Shorter xylophone bars produce high notes and longer xylophone bars produce lower notes.

The bars of a xylophone are strung together with string or cord and held in place while being able to vibrate when struck with the mallet to produce sound.

Concert xylophones have tube resonators below the bars to enhance the tone and sustain. Frames are made of wood or cheap steel tubing: more expensive xylophones feature height adjustment and more stability in the stand.

The sound produced from the xylophone depends heavily on the skill of the player. The player stands to play the xylophone and faces the center of the instrument.

Jazz musicians often used the xylophone in their bands until the vibraphone became more popular in this style of music in the 1940s.

facts.name: Gained popularity internationally in the 1800s
facts.value: The xylophone gained popularity internationally in the 1800s when the Russian musician Michael Josef Gusikov toured with his instrument.

facts.name: Xylophones used in concert halls often have 42 to 48 wooden bars
facts.value: Xylophones used in concert halls often have 42 to 48 wooden bars and are similar in appearance to a keyboard.

facts.name: The bars often made of rosewood or Kelon
facts.value: The bars of a xylophone are often made of rosewood or Kelon (a type of fiberglass).

facts.name: Used in elementary school for musical education
facts.value: Xylophones are often used in elementary school musical education classes.

facts.name: Popular in ragtime music
facts.value: In the 1970s the xylophone became popular in ragtime music.

facts.name: The early xylophones in Asia were often created with wooden bars
facts.value: The early xylophones in Asia were often created with wooden bars attached to gourds. Today the frame of the xylophone is made of wood or metal.

facts.name: Used for sound effects in movies
facts.value: The xylophone has also been used for sound effects in movies as can be used to mimic the sound of bones clanging together.

facts.name: First time used in an orchestra in 1893
facts.value: The first time a xylophone was used in an orchestra for the opera Hansel and Gretel by Engelbert Humperdinck (Arnold George Dorsey), a German Composer, in 1893.

facts.name: Mallets can be made of a variety of mater
facts.value: Mallets used for the xylophone can be made of a variety of material including wood, metal, or rubber.

facts.name: The African xylophone is referred to as the balafon
facts.value: The African xylophone is referred to as the balafon; in Mozambique the xylophone is referred to as the Mbilia; in Ghana, Burkina Faso, Mali, and West Africa the xylophone is referred to as the gyil; in western Zambia the xylophone is referred to as the silimba.

facts.name: Bars are created with different lengths
facts.value: Bars of the xylophone are created with different lengths, which produce different sounds.

facts.name: Has been used for other purposes than music
facts.value: The xylophone has been used for purposes other than music. In Senegal it was used to scare monkeys and birds and other pests from people's gardens.

facts.name: The type of used wood results in different sounds
facts.value: The type of wood used to create the bars of the xylophone can result in different sounds. Hardwood is the most common but bamboo has also been used.

facts.name: Between 1910 and 1940 was popular in vaudeville acts
facts.value: Between 1910 and 1940 the xylophone was popular in vaudeville acts.
